author: tom mcnichol
text: gamesit took nearly six hours, but 34-year-old billy mitchell accomplished a feat that has eluded mere mortals: he recorded the first-ever perfect score in pac-man. without losing a single man, the fort lauderdale gamer gobbled every dot, energizer, blue man, and piece of fruit to reach the holy grail of pac-man - board 256, where the game runs out of memory and ends with a split screen."one in a hundred million people has seen that screen," says an awed mitchell.a self-confessed joystick junkie, mitchell set a world record in donkey kong at age 17, before turning his attention to pac-man. in july, with a camcorder taping his pac-man's every turn, mitchell scored 3,333,360 points, the maximum allowed by the game."it was a day," he said, "when all of the elements came together."having beaten pac-man at his own game, mitchell at first planned to retire from competition. but with the october release of pac-man world, a playstation version of the arcade game, mitchell sees new pac-worlds to conquer.says mitchell: "it's hard to pass up the challenge of staying ahead of millions of players in the home market."must readhot tongue actionpower exchangenaughty bitsstupid net lawsthe lewis and clark expeditionclark's remarkstired/wiredpeoplejargon watchthe wages of simpac-ratinstant replaypc and a blow-drygimme redmondraw data
